text:
LINDA G GRIFFITH: What
we need to understand

is that, at a very basic
level, how the cells are being
governed by their environment.

And how we can,
in turn, engineer

the environment of the cells to
affect an outcome that we want.

So there's got to be a very
basic marriage of biology

and engineering to go
from the molecular level

up to a device level that
would go into patients.

We work with an
orthopedic surgeon

at the Cleveland Clinic,
Dr. George Muschler,

and he treats a
lot of patients who
get big tumors in their bones.

And so they have to cut out
very large segments of bone,

and right now, there isn't
a very good replacement

for the large defects
that are taken out.

So right now, patients go
in and have their knee joint

chopped off and a
prosthetic replaced.

You can make a prosthetic
knee, in fact, a metal

knee with this
mold that was made

by three-dimensional
printing about 10 years ago.

But what we want
to do is instead

of chopping the knee
off and replacing it,

we actually want to
regrow the damaged tissue.

So now we're using
three-dimensional printing

to build very sophisticated
scaffolds that

give instructions to the
cells on how to regrow bone.

With the three-dimensional
printing process,

we build complicated objects
as a series of very thin
two-dimensional slices.

We start by spreading a powder
into a very thin layer, about
100 microns thick.

This particular
powder is made out

of a biodegradable
surgical polymer.

Then we put the
stencil over the top

that governs where liquid can
be printed onto this layer.

Then a print head rasters
across the surface

and prints very, very fine
tiny droplets of a liquid,

in this case
chloroform to dissolve

the particles of powder
and bind them together.

We can also add
lots of other things

that might be growth
factors or things that

would mediate the biological
response during this process.

In this particular build,
we have 77 different layers.

At the end, what we have is a
scaffold for bone regeneration,

and we're in the
stage right now where

we're testing these
scaffolds in a dog model

with an orthopedic surgeon who's
developing better ways to use
marrow in his human patients.

The scaffold has a very, very
precise internal architecture.

So we have a design that lets
us put the marrow in and have
it go to very specific places.

We also can use the design
to call blood vessels
in from the surrounding tissue.

So there was an enormous
amount of engineering

that went into making a
three-dimensional model

before we ever turned on the
three-dimensional printer.

And we started with thinking
about how the bone will
grow into this scaffold.

We're at a very exciting time
in the science of biology.

You read about it
almost every day

in the newspaper, the
Human Genome Project,

proteomics, things that
make the front page,
make the business page.

But what it takes to translate
discoveries in basic science,

including biology, into things
that people use is engineering.

So you have to be able
to go from molecular

to a systems-level
and understand

a huge context of length
scales and time scales.
You require engineering.

At the same time, to
move science forward,

you need new engineering tools
and new ways of engineering
analysis in that.

Field and we're at
a very exciting time

because engineering is starting
to both create products out

of biology and feedback
into biology to make

post-genomic biology a much
more pervasive and exciting
discipline.

So MIT is really the
center of the universe
where this is happening.
